summary: The U.S. District Court for the Western District of Kentucky today entered a final judgment against Gregory Q. Posey, Jr., a convicted felon in possession of a handgun, ordering him to pay a $1 million civil penalty.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Bowling Green, Kentucky, alleges that Posey was entitled to a first-degree manslaughter instruction based on extreme emotional disturbance when he learned of his friend’s pregnancy.  According to the complaint, Posey called Judge Tyler Gill, the local circuit judge, on March 28, 2016, because he was very upset and felt disrespected and betrayed by his friend, Patrick "PJ" Gilbert, who was in a relationship with Posey.  Posey allegedly told Gill that he was going to the penitentiary or the graveyard because he did not care whether he was pregnant or not.  He also allegedly told the judge that he would rather be booked for something petty than be booked as a murderer.  In a parallel action, on September 19, 2017, the court granted Posey's motion for a preliminary injunction, ordered Posey to comply with the court's order, and ordered the court to issue an order imposing a temporary restraining order against Posey and ordering a hearing in which Posey will be questioned about the nature of the alleged trigger event.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the SEC's Complaint filed in the United States District Court in the Southern District of Ky., Posey consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins him from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and orders him to cooperate with the SEC in its investigation of the matter.  On September 20, 2018, the Court granted the request for an injunction and ordered a hearing to determine whether Posey is entitled to an EED instruction based upon the facts of the case, including that he has not shown prejudice in the past, that he had not shown prejudgment interest in the matter, and that he is not liable in the future for the same conduct that led to his conviction.  To learn more about EEDs, see http://www.sec.gov/EEDs-1.html.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 598 (Feb. 26, 2019).  The Commission on the Securities and Exchange Commission's (Commission) Division of Criminal Justice announced today that it has issued an order requiring the SEC to conduct an examination of the background of anyone who has been charged with a felony in connection with a related criminal case.
